bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
Hon. Secretary of State Dear Sir,
My duties call me again to Gaboon, Africa the so port sail form San Lark are Liverpool, England the last of this month. I shall be very sad I receive any special instructions from you addressed to 23 Centre JL.N.Y. or I will go to Nashington if necessary.
The situation there as of appears me and out fellow missionary seemed to warrent French aggression and occasion of territory and I firmly believe that they will not be content without the Congo country is under there authority for we of this t have felt this to myself be most of *unclear*
to and to Gaboon one goes his while attention of this and ehite in this emmity have on the land and for sords one I could recommend Africa weeks ago I met a young man when I formerly knew in college a young man of sterling Christian Character and marked ability who a pressed himself as willing to spend a few years there. I therefore recommend Royal F. King, nephew of Hon. Worm King of Minnesota, either for the petition with which you have honored which I will glady resign a accept the vice commercial agency or to any other position you might see full to appoint him. He has seen some service under the Department of the Indian among the Indians where the temptations + young are similar to them on the coast, and I there Lore Commandant his
United States Commercial Agent at Gaboon
Mr, Busnell To the Department of State
Subject, Visit of United States Steamer Essex at Gaboon
Sir,
I have the honor to inform you that we have recently received a visit at this port, from the United States Steamers Essex Commander W.L.Sehley she remained a such during which time we enjoyed the plesant society of Commander Schlet and hiis gentlemanly offices from whom we received my kind and courteous attentions. Permit me to make honorable mention of the French Commandant Crpt. J. Borton who simply furnished Commandert Schley first all neefull supplies to ,ale him to continue his voyage to the Congo and
So Paul de Lundo. The visit of this beautiful ship, with her truly Patriotu gentlemanly Commander and offices, will promoite American interest in this part of Africa; and I trust in future, we may more frequently recieve visity from our national vessels than we have done since the late war.
I beg to remain Sir;
Most respectfully, Your obedient Servant Albert Bushnell U.S.Com. Agent
